events.target_title: support user-supplied mount options
support user-supplied mount options

note.body:
Thanks for the comments, and thanks for pointing out `GVfsUDisks2VolumeMonitor`, which is where the patch should be done in the first place. There is indeed a fallback to `mount` in several cases, but most of the time mounting a block device (especially an external one) is done through `udisks2`, which supports options. Without going through polkit, one could provide a way to supply mount options and give a warning if `mount` fallback was used and options couldn't be enforced.

Digging on `GVfsUDisks2VolumeMonitor`, I found two old bug reports: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/issues/97 and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gvfs/issues/100 related to what I'm suggesting, but the last comment was done several years ago. Should I open a new bug report on the `gvfs` project?

Regarding `gnome-disk-utility`, I'm not on a full gnome desktop, I'm only using some components here and there, such as `gio` and `gvfs`. Moreover, the `/etc/fstab` has some inherent shortcomings: you need one line per device and can't give defaults for, say, "all external drives" or "all fat filesystems".

events.target_title: support user-supplied mount options

note.body:
Sorry I should have explained my use-case before: it is a file explorer where one can mount usb sticks and the like through a gui. Then the configuration options can be in gio or in the file explorer (with a config file or a right-click option for example), either would be ok. If this configuration was to be made in the file explorer I would need a way to pass the options to gio, hence the feature request.

The mount options I need to apply are not specific to vfat. For example I need a way to specify `windows_names` option for ntfs, `nls` for hfs+, `errors` for exfat, but also generic options such as `exec`/`noexec` or `ro`/`rw`.

events.target_title: support user-supplied mount options
support user-supplied mount options

note.body: Hi Philip, and thanks for your input on this. I'm trying to use an approach that is as abstract as possible and gio seems to be the perfect library for this. I'm reluctant on using udisks directly since I want to be able to mount all sorts of things, not only block devices, so I'm already using gio anyway. Having to deal with both gio and udisks seems complicated and bug-prone, especially since all the features could be provided through gio. Moreover, mount options can also be given when mounting e.g. nfs shares which, if I'm correct, don't go through udisks. Hence mount options in gio are not specific to udisks and make a lot of sense, in my opinion. Is there a consensus on gnome's side that this feature is too specific for gio?

events.target_title: support user-supplied mount options

note.body:
Actually I do have `gvfsd-nfs` in mind. The idea would be for `gio` to pass options to several backends, including `gvfsd-nfs` and `udisks2`.
If I understand correctly you are saying that this feature is not a priority since there is no pressure for it from designers or from other projects. I can understand that in this situation you do not want to spend time implementing it. However, does closing the issue mean that you are not willing to include it if me or someone else submits a pull request? I'd like to know so I don't spend time implementing something that will never get integrated into `gio`. Also, if you are not willing to include it, what is the reason (I'm not discussing your choices, just trying to understand)?

events.target_title: support user-supplied mount options

note.body:
I see your point. I'm surprised that Nautilus never considered such a feature but indeed maintaining a large library is a lot of work and I understand you don't want to include every API change proposal.

Thanks for having taken the time to answer!

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
If anyone is interested, I am actively maintaining a CMake-based buildsystem for libxml2 at https://github.com/robotology-dependencies/libxml2-cmake-buildsystem (mainly for cross-compilation using CMake).

It has not been tested in a lot of situations and it still miss support for some features supported by the official build system of libxml2, but it may be relevant for people interested in CMake support for building libxml2.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body: That's great @nwellnhof, I did not noticed that PR, thanks for the link.

events.target_title: WIP: CMake support

note.body: Since CMake 3.11, CMake ships its own `FindIconv.cmake` module (see https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/v3.14.2/Modules/FindIconv.cmake and https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.14/module/FindIconv.html). Could it make sense to use their own module, and if we want to keep compatibility with CMake < 3.11, temporarily vendor their version, or define the same variables and imported targets as the official CMake module?

events.target_title: WIP: CMake support

note.body: A possible way of integrating external libraries in a CMake project is to download them via the [`FetchContent`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.11/module/FetchContent.html) module, and then call `add_subdirectory` on the source directory of the project. In that case, the CMake options of the third party project as exposed as options of the bigger project, and so for clarity and for avoiding collisions it may be convenient to prefix the CMake options with a project-specific prefix. In https://github.com/robotology-dependencies/libxml2-cmake-buildsystem#options I use the `LIBXML2_` prefix, do you think it could make sense to use the same strategy here?

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
@rickert I saw that in your CMake build system you use options in the form `WITH_<>`. However, a possible way of integrating external libraries in a CMake project is to download them via the [`FetchContent`](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.11/module/FetchContent.html) module, and then call `add_subdirectory` on the source directory of the project. In that case, the CMake options of the third party project as exposed as options of the bigger project, and so for clarity and for avoiding collisions it may be convenient to prefix the CMake options with a project-specific prefix. In https://github.com/robotology-dependencies/libxml2-cmake-buildsystem#options I use the `LIBXML2_` prefix, do you think it could make sense to use the same strategy here?

See original comment in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/libxml2/merge_requests/9#note_491202 .

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body: That is great @rickert ! Hopefully in the next weeks I will try to switch our internal project that is using https://github.com/robotology-dependencies/libxml2-cmake-buildsystem to your new build system, and I will report if there are any specific issues, thanks a lot.

events.target_title: Support <connection> XML element in importer
Implement OpenVPN 2.4 Compression Options

note.body: According to my testing `--compress` is not the same as `--comp-lzo adaptive`. I have a setup where the server uses OpenVPN 2.4.6 with `--compress` and the only way I could get my OpenVPN 2.4.6 client to connect was to change `--comp-lzo adaptive` to `--compress`. Without it, I get the error "Bad LZO decompression header byte: 251".

events.target_title: Implement OpenVPN 2.4 Compression Options

note.body:
I made a patched version of the network-manager-openvpn and network-manager-openvpn-gnome packages. The network-manager-openvpn package changes the flag passed to the underlying openvpn from `--comp-lzo` to `--compress`. Select "LZO Compression" in the UI. The network-manager-openvpn-gnome package has no changes, it's just to keep the version numbers identical.

I'm attaching the patch file which, IIRC, you can drop into the patches directory of the Debian or Ubuntu source package and build it. I'm also attaching the binary packages I built from it. They're a little old by now so you might find that Apt likes to replace them with newer versions. You can use Apt pinning to force Apt to hold onto these specific versions.

This is a hack, but it might help get you running until this ticket is resolved and delivered by distros.

Patch: [nm-openvpn.patch](/uploads/b49fb69bdb5c74af2be8bbde67d8d0a9/nm-openvpn.patch)

[network-manager-openvpn_1.8.8-2.1+0.tedjp1_amd64.deb](/uploads/9e20b6dcbeef4a42b7b121b1c6b089be/network-manager-openvpn_1.8.8-2.1+0.tedjp1_amd64.deb)

[network-manager-openvpn-gnome_1.8.8-2.1+0.tedjp1_amd64.deb](/uploads/53c1238081b40b80361eb210bbb8b13d/network-manager-openvpn-gnome_1.8.8-2.1+0.tedjp1_amd64.deb)

CC: @bernhard.schussek

We'll be switching from Ubuntu 16.04 soon and we're hoping this gets fixed to save us from a support ticket every time someone changes their password.

note.body:
```xml
<interface>
  <!-- interface-requires gtk+ 3.24 -->
  <template class="MeldWindow" parent="GtkApplicationWindow">
    <property name="name">meldapp</property>
    <property name="height_request">400</property>
    <property name="can_focus">False</property>
    <property name="title" translatable="yes">Meld</property>
 **   <property name="icon_name">org.gnome.meld</property>**
    <property name="show-menubar">false</property>
    <signal name="delete-event" handler="on_delete_event" swapped="no"/>
```

I think the problem is that the org.gnome.meld file doesn't exist. The file identifier is actually org.gnome.meld.ico.

events.target_title: this._player.trackArtists.join is not a function
GNOME Calendar does not add calendar subscriptions from the web

note.body:
I also had the same problem (Ubuntu 19.04 with Gnome 3.32) as described above. For me, the solution by @pieterhollander also workarounds the problem. The exact steps were:
1. Install `evolution`
2. Do the basic setup in `evolution`
3. Add your web calendar in `evolution`
4. Reopen `gnome-calendar` --> you will see the added calendar and all its events
5. Do NOT remove `evolution` again, as that will result in regular crashes of `gnome-calendar` when trying to change the properties of the just added calendar

@feaneron Might it be that we just have some missing packages/dependencies when shipping `gnome-calendar`?

events.target_title: Perpetual move cursor

note.body: Hi. I use Blender, GIMP and Inkscape daily in my line of work and I often accidentally try to use blender's shortcuts and/or expect a certain behavior from blender whenever I switch applications. Having this feature in GIMP would certainly ease those transitions and increase productivity in some cases. I don't use a tablet so I can't speak for some tablet woes this might add, so I think having this as an optional feature would be the best of both worlds.

events.target_title: read emails not marked as read

note.body:
I can confirm this bug (Arch, latest master, built from [AUR package](https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/geary-git/)). It happens even with a clean config.

The bug did not happen with my previous build (commit 668e4b46). I assume it is related to 3d51863788563d7db100cb19793dd5a973363a45 *Merge branch 'wip/794700-lazy-load-conversations' into 'master'*...

events.target_title: Error when forwarding an email
Error when forwarding an email

note.body: Well yeah, kind of. I was affected by #581 as well, but this one is a bit different, since Geary does not crash anymore. The underlying problem of #581 doesn't seem to be fixed - only the crash.

events.target_title: Error when forwarding an email

note.body:

note.body:
> actually the right place to put this code is here https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/fractal/blob/aafd8096c596d4ec9ddd2389b59ff7b3f841f00d/fractal-gtk/src/actions/global.rs#L228
Can you ask on gnome-hackers what the best method is to connect a action to a button press?

Thanks for the pointer to that room, I couldn't find a list of IRC and/or Matrix rooms for GNOME and/or GTK anywhere. Someone in IRC confirmed that it's not possible to setup an accelerator for a mouse button. I can at least move the `connect_button_press_event` to be next to that line though.

> Did you check what other applications use for that, @azdle?

I did, I only found raw numbers being used with that API call. It's already used just like that in this project already for a right-click handler:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/fractal/blob/master/fractal-gtk/src/widgets/message.rs#L503

note.body:
Sorry for my ignorance but I can't agree.  

When I enter a number followed with an **exponent** (via the *x10^y* key, [*CTRL+E*] shortcut key, the tooltip reads "*Scientific exponent*") I would expect the number with a given number of zeros.  

So 6×10¹³ ÷ 2×10⁹ means for me 60000000000000 / 2000000000 (with all the consequences).

events.target_title: Crashes when loading app
Crashes when loading app

note.body:
>  Hi, are you sure? Version 2.2.1 was released in the year 2004.

Then probably not, given that I downloaded a new update in November.

In the E:\PortableApps\GIMPPortable folder there is a GIMPPortable.exe file. Going to app properties, it says that it was both created and modified ‎Thursday, ‎December ‎6, ‎2018, ‏‎10:11:40 AM. In the details tab it gives the product version and file version as 2.2.1.0.

In the E:\PortableApps\GIMPPortable\App\gimp\bin folder there is a gimp-2.10.exe file. Going to app properties, it says that it was both created and modified ‎‎Friday, ‎November ‎9, ‎2018, ‏‎10:14:04 PM. In the details tab it gives the product version and file version as 2.10.8 (.0). I double clicked that file and had the same thing happen -- the initializing window appeared and then died after hitting 'modules'.

>  Please use the command prompt and report the output shown the GIMP crashes: https://wiki.gimp.org/wiki/Users:Tips#Getting_and_posting_the_output_of_gimp_--verbose

I tried. I followed all the instructions, other than changing the path. But, as I said, the command prompt window died at the same time as the initializing window.

note.body:
Sorry for not replying earlier - I used email and it failed.\
Here's the email I sent:
 For Andre's question:

I've enclosed two small screen snapshots showing both choices. It seems to be 12-point fonts, Sans Regular and Monospace Regular that are listed. It doesn't matter whether the checkbox is checked or not: when Evolution starts: the addresses, etc., do not appear unless I change the setting. Changing it fixes the display, and changing it back again does not break it. Once fixed, it is OK until Evolution is restarted.

The problem is in the email message contents an headers, not the list of messages in top panel. The cases I've noticed seem to involve underlined text. I've enclosed a screenshot of that case too, using the email I received as an example.

I didn't report it to System 76 yet as I've only seen this behavior with Evolution. If it was a problem with System 76's fonts, after changing the setting, exiting from Evolution, and restarting, I'd expect it to stay fixed, but that is not what happens: regardless of the initial setting, the problem reoccurs until I change the
setting again.

For Milan's question:

If I select the link, the background is a light blue and the text is
black.

If I subsequently open the preferences dialog box and then click on the
"use same fonts as other applications" checkbox twice (deselecting it
and then reselecting it), then when I select the text, the background
becomes the same shade of blue and the text appears as black text. The
only difference in behavior is that the text is then visible when it is
not selected.

Evolution does not read GNUPGHOME
Evolution does not read GNUPGHOME

note.body:
evolution 3.30.4

I use/would-like-to-use special hardware device for signing and encrypting. I [set up](https://github.com/romanz/trezor-agent/blob/master/doc/INSTALL.md) and use [custom gpg-agent](https://github.com/romanz/trezor-agent/blob/master/doc/README-GPG.md): trezor-gpg-agent.

Normally gpg.conf, pubring, trustdb etc... are located in `~/.gnupg`. If I set up trezor-gpg environment, subdirectory `~/.gnupg/trezor` is created with its own gpg.conf, pubring, trustdb etc...
Running, for example, `gpg -k` lists standard list of public keys; `GNUPGHOME="$HOME/.gnupg/trezor" gpg -k` lists public keys on my hardware device.
Similarly:
```bash 
$ thunderbird                                    #sees standard keyring
$ GNUPGHOME="$HOME/.gnupg/trezor" thunderbird    #sees hw-keys
```
but
```bash 
$ evolution                                    #sees standard keyring
$ GNUPGHOME="$HOME/.gnupg/trezor" evolution    #sees standard keyring
```

events.target_title: Evolution does not read GNUPGHOME

Thanks for reply.
I finally got that working. I supplied, as you suggested, custom binary to check for that variable. It printed correct value. So I tried it once more: ignored pgp-key suggestions, which were probably cached, and hard-typed the key-ID. I should've tried it straight away. Thanks

cat 
`/var/lib/snapd/desktop/applications/slack_slack.desktop`:

```
[Desktop Entry]
Name=Slack
Comment=Slack Desktop
GenericName=Slack Client for Linux

Icon=/snap/slack/11/usr/share/pixmaps/slack.png

StartupNotify=true
Categories=GNOME;GTK;Network;InstantMessaging;

```

`/home/<user>/.local/share/applications/userapp-Firefox-FMXZWZ.desktop`:

events.target_title: Exceptionally slow drawing performance in GIMP 2.10.4 compared to 2.8.16

note.body:
This seems to be linked to the type of profile, my monitor profile was created using displaycal as "XYZ LUT + Matrix", whenever I set Gimp to use the system profile it becomes almost unusable.
So I created a "Curves + Matrix"-Profile from the measurements, unchecked the "use system profile"-option and manually selected the newly created profile which greatly improves responsiveness.
I'm attaching the performance log.
Picture information:
4672 × 3104 Pixel, 32 bit TIFF-file
Actions: zooming in at 200% from 25%

events.target_title: Option to specify the format for the modification time column
Can I tell which versions of a file actually differ in 3-way dir comparison?

note.body:
I have a similar use case and came up with a workaround. I wrote a script `sync-mtimes` ([sync-mtimes](/uploads/b7061f49192d430fa52786465a17ab78/sync-mtimes)) that synchronizes mtimes for duplicates in a duplicate group to the oldest mtime. This script should be started with the directory names that will be used in the `meld` call.

In addition, one can change the date-time format in the modification column to something more compact that starts with the time part:
`DATETIME_FORMAT = "%H:%M:%S %Y%m%d"`
(in file meld/ui/cellrenderers.py).

Now, a row with 2 identical versions and 1 isolated version can be easily detected by looking at the time part of the corresponding columns.

note.body:
Thanks for your reply.

I'd love to try but I don't understand what you mean by *"test to see if the issue is with one of these tools by running the related  command from the gparted.in script"*? That's over my head, sorry.

When I "sudo parted -l" or "sudo parted /dev/sda print unit s print unit chs print" nothing will happen in respect to GNOME Disks.

As I see it, the issue is twofold:

**a)** Re lock on devices:
Basically OK but why when opening GParted? Nemo does not and Disks does not, both will update the display automatically when e.g. automounting a drive.
The problem here is the required authentication **at the start** of GParted, without intent to change anything. It's not necessary (at least not obvious).
Lock should be done only before writing changes to the system ("are you sure? Authenticate now").
Btw. GNOME Disks does not indicate that anything would be locked when GParted is open, it seems I could resize partition 2 even if it is "0.0 KB Unknown", the rest is shown as "Free Space 333 GB" but I have swap and Mint installed there!

**b)** Forget to clean up:
Opening GParted writes "something" to the system at authentication, and it forgets to take that back even when GParted is closed. This is the **real** problem.

See attached file: ![Disks_tool_strange](/uploads/7c3416dd05ad56e399622df7318741d3/Disks_tool_strange.png)

And I think it's only in context of an extended partition, on my /dev/sdb it's OK.

Please tell me what I could do to gather more information for you but take care, I'm a n00b ;-)

"udisksctl dump" does what one would expect, it's only the presentation in the terminal window that's strange, even if done by **"others"**.

I'm a fan of different - if it's for the better.
To be clear, this is not.

Ctrl+a (not A) with Win and (cmd+) Mac would select all, and ctrl+c (not C) would copy. Ctrl+shift+C is difficult to achieve but does it in Linux, yes, that's my fault, I basically knew it is d...

Please enable that command in case it would collect the output from the alternate screen, otherwise remove it from the Help pages.

Don't get me wrong, to be "different" is sometimes cool, but it's also the reason why Linux is still below 5% on the desktops. Both others already do their best to disappoint the users, so please give Linux a chance!

Thank you again.

note.body:
Ouch, my bad with "gedit", sorry!

But first (I don't know if it's of importance), re your last point 1.:

> A text shell script file called "**gparted**" in "/usr/bin". 

The gparted (script file) never was in `/usr/bin/` but in `/usr/**sbin**/`, your suggested cp -p ... failed, see my last reply: I've taken it from /usr/sbin/ to create the /usr/bin/mygparted.

However, now I understand your testing the shell script separated from the binary start. (I've deleted the extra copied gpartedbin now)

I don't have gedit but nemo installed, it starts from a terminal (with some permission denied messages):
`sudo mytestgparted`
now started GUI nemo editor (with elevated privileges and some sharing complaints in terminal) -

But GNOME Disks still had the extended partition displayed, with all detail partitions and the correct free space at the end.

I've tried that several times, with Disks already open or opened after the script opening nemo, same result.

It's the binary "gpartedbin" that causes the problem to GNOME Disks, the script is OK so far.

Out of curiosity now I started `mytestgparted` directly without sudo, got the "Authenticate" window, sending that opens GParted GUI and immediately causes Disks to lose information regarding the extended partition (terminal reports "Too few arguments. libparted: 3.2").

-WTF? There is only one mytestgparted in /usr/bin, it's the script, and therein is BASE_CMD="/usr/bin/nemo $*" written? Why gpartedbin or memo depending on sudo???

OK, I learned a lot but aren't any the wiser, on the contrary, ... What's next?

**PS:**
I found that "udisksctl dump" reflects the change and the problem for Disks when gparted was started, so I've added that files before and after invoking GParted from Mint GUI, just in case.

Again, my main issue is that when GParted is closed, without doing anything in it, something permanently  remains changed in the system.

This is the culprit: After some weeks Disks would be used and it may damage the partition it is running on.

events.target_title: Allow left/right arrow keys to change a file to preview

note.body:
I mistakenly opened the same bug on nautilus#849 yesterday, nice to see that others wished the same :) I’ll just add one info about the behaviour of this feature, it is quite obvious when used to macOS but can easily be missed when implementing:

Changing the file previewed in Sushi also changes which file is selected in Nautilus underneath. So when space is pressed again to close Sushi after seeing a series of files, the file selected in the file browser is the one that was shown last in the pop-up (as opposed to the one that was selected when Sushi was first opened, as would happen if opening EOG instead of Sushi for instance). 

It is quite important to make the feature really useful.

note.body:
Tried running latest commits from master on mutter and Gnome-shell and updated all the dependencies to latest version too and sadly the same behaviur still exists. As @adee points out i have the same issue as him. Happens on Wayland version too and due to this bug Wayland is basically unusable because on start its smooth but again after those ~10 seconds it causes the cursor to "jump" and after that the animations from app overview to the thing on right in app overview where you can see virtual desktops. I have this laptop for 4 months now and this was an issue from the beggining. On start i tought that this was because without AC power the CPU runs at 1.6Ghz but sadly this issue was there even if i plug the laptop in and at that point the CPU can run at full 3.6GHz. @vanvugt I can confirm this is an issue even if i just let the PC run for the 10 seconds without even touching the mouse. the animations are not smooth at all in entire GNOME not only in overview. Also CPU usage is always the same before the mouse "jump" or after.

One log message i find interesting and that is most likely the cause of this issue is: Unrecoverable failure in required component org.gnome.Shell.desktop and this appears in logs right after the "jump".
Checked multiple times if it wasnt there before the jump i had to be fast to open the Logs app but i can confirm that this log message isnt there before the mouse "jump".
Is there anyway i can check what exactly fails and causes this message to show up ?

events.target_title: Expose HTTPS clone URI in the API
Some modules are not visible in the listing API
Some modules are not visible in the listing API

note.body:
Thanks for the reply.

For my information, what are the conditions for a project to be "archived"?  
Does this mean the whole project is dead or is this just that the translation is no longer handled on Damned-Lies?  
Alacarte may be really dead, but I did not study all other archived modules.

In fact I want to use the API to discover all "GNOME" translatable projects (for the Deckard project), so I would like to know if I can just ignore archived projects or if I should plan to aggregate other sources than the D-L API in order to get everything.

events.target_title: Some modules are not visible in the listing API

note.body:
Ok, thanks, fine with me.  
I let you close the issue if you want.

Some suggestions anyway:
* Maybe you could envision an `archived` attribute on modules, so that it is more explicit?
* The fact that archived modules are not listed should probably be documented somewhere
* Add an optional parameter to list archived modules?

Thanks again.

events.target_title: Expose HTTPS clone URI in the API

note.body:
Thanks for the reply.

It's not as simple, because some module are actually hosted elsewhere than in https://gitlab.gnome.org:
I looped on all modules and saw things from GitHub, cgit.freedesktop.org, gitlab.freedesktop.org and even svn.webkit.org.  
Re-constructing the clone URI can still be done, but corner cases will be boring. So if D-L have them already, it would save me some time :)

Also I saw even `vcs_web` links are not always up-to-date. For example `gst-plugins-bad` gives https://cgit.freedesktop.org/gstreamer/gst-plugins-bad but it is really https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/gstreamer/gst-plugins-bad

By the way, for my information, what is the point of having modules with the `ext_platform` attribute? If these modules are not translatable in D-L, why are they even listed in the API?

events.target_title: Some modules are not visible in the listing API

note.body: Perfect, thanks!

events.target_title: Expose HTTPS clone URI in the API

note.body:
> Then it will be boring for us! What's the point of storing data we don't use?

Well, I did not study how D-L is implemented and from where it gets its data.  
I thought that if the API already exposed SSH url, it also had access the HTTPS ones and that it was just a matter of exposing them in the API.

Of course, I'm not asking to implement any extra logic, especially if it would only be useful in my specific use case.

So, to sum-up, what I understood is that I should only rely on `vcs_web` and that I can probably just ignore all modules that have an `ext_platform` link.

Thanks for the explanations.

note.body:
"Do you have the glib docs installed? If you are building from scratch this is expected and I should maybe skip those checks when glib docs are not there."

I have installed [GLib-2.56.1](http://www.linuxfromscratch.org/blfs/downloads/stable/BLFS-BOOK-8.3-nochunks.html#glib2) and I followed the instructions. I can't remember there being anything similar to glib docs. 

I also have [GTK-Doc-1.28](http://www.linuxfromscratch.org/blfs/downloads/stable/BLFS-BOOK-8.3-nochunks.html#gtk-doc) installed.

Should I list what I have installed?

events.target_title: test "FAIL: sanity.sh" when installing GTK-DOC-1.28

note.body:
I did ignore the test the first time around. I only came back to it when I tried to install other packages and those packages would throw a warning or error. Some of them wouldn't install; for example I did `./configure --enable-gtk` and then `make` would throw an error. So eventually I either had to not use the `--enable-gtk` or, if the package continued to give errors and fail, then I had to explicitly state `./configure --disable-gtk` to get the packages to build.

Most packages, when using `--enable-gtk`, would show the warnings that were the same as all of those errors above like `ERROR: no ID for constraint linkend: "GObject"`

After repeatedly getting these errors and having to use `--disable-gtk`, I went back and tried to reinstall a bunch of packages thinking I must have made a mistake somewhere. Eventually I got back to reinstalling GTK-doc 1.28 and it dumped all of these errors, which means there is something wrong with this particular package.

Anyways, I only submitted the bug because it told me to submit it. I guess it's not actually a big deal.

events.target_title: Gimp 2.10 crash while trying to drag layer to layer group
Gimp 2.10 crash while trying to drag layer to layer group

note.body:
Hi Jehan,

This is in Gimp 2.10.8.  I currently have a strange workaround. I initially downloaded 2.10.8 via Gimp.org.  However, this didn't come with G'MIC.  I couldn't find an install of G'MIC, except thru Partha's site, which you could only get thru downloading pkg McGimp.   But that kept crashing as described. 
   I went back to my initial download from Gimp.org.  I then copied G'MIC from McGimp.  I inserted that copy into the 2.10.8 plug-ins.  
   So far that's what's working without a hitch.  

  Hope this info is helpful. 

Stay well. 
Ken

events.target_title: Meld Windows shows error on startup "There was a problem starting c:\Program"

note.body: I also had this happening to me when I installed meld on drive d. I installed it on drive c and it worked fine. Perhaps it's using a hard-coded path, or maybe instead of getting the installed path, it's getting the default path to program files. Anyway, that's what happened to me.

events.target_title: Music get paused randomly after few seconds
New unlock/login design

note.body:
With all the debate about how to deal with the "hidden" password entry field and accidental input, I hope we can all at least agree on this:

Showing the login field to enter a password is by far the most intuitive and frictionless approach for users to know to enter their password.

There should be no disagreement there. It may be that the screen should be made less intuitive for other good reasons, though.

It seems from this discussion that the login field is hidden either to prevent accidental login on certain devices, or to increase screen space available for notifications.

In the circumstance that the device isn't a phone or tablet there is no need to prevent accidental input. In the circumstance that there are no notifications, or abundant screen space, then there is no need to hide the login field.

So why not make the visibility of the login field reactive to these cases, with a clear hint for when it is hidden?

Distribute Windows ZIP archives in addition to installers
Distribute Windows ZIP archives in addition to installers

note.body:
@Jehan Thanks for the answer :slightly\_smiling\_face:

The GIMP Windows installer offers CLI arguments for unattended installation (see [here](https://github.com/lukesampson/scoop-extras/blob/45612fbae3542094e36d7f18f31761dfb988a7ad/bucket/gimp.json#L7-L13) for how it's used in Scoop), but it also requests administrator privileges which causes an [UAC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User_Account_Control) prompt to appear (the installation will pause until the prompt is accepted). Most other applications in Scoop don't have that issue, as they offer ZIP archives or installers which can be extracted statically (this is the ideal option).

Unfortunately, to my knowledge, GIMP's installer cannot be extracted statically ~~as it doesn't use a standard installer creation program such as NSIS, Inno Setup or WiX.~~ ("Extracted statically" means the files are extracted without any installer code being run, using a third-party program.)

Of course, one can also disable UAC, but that makes it possible for *any* application to run privileged operations without asking the user, which is a security risk.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
Maybe also interesting for you: we've added CMake support for the third-party dependencies of our project, including libiconv, zlib, liblzma, libxml2, and libxslt. The main reason was to make it easier for our users to build them on Windows. https://github.com/roboticslibrary/libiconv/tree/patch-2
https://github.com/roboticslibrary/zlib/tree/patch
https://github.com/roboticslibrary/xz/tree/patch
https://github.com/roboticslibrary/libxml2/tree/patch
https://github.com/roboticslibrary/libxslt/tree/patch libiconv requires autogen.sh to generate the distributed files (aliases, flags etc.) included in the release tarballs, the others work directly. We would also be interested in integrating these into the upstream versions.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
Some background on my patch: I tried to be as close as possible to the current configure script, including the checks for available headers and functions. For MSVC it currently stays close to Makefile.msvc and uses the existing win32config.h. The extensive checks take longer on MSVC, but I guess it should be possible to avoid separate config files in the long run if this works and is desired.

The CMake script uses target definitions with all includes, compile definitions, and linked libraries so they can be exported and automatically included when linking to the libxml2 target. The currently used capitalization "libxml2::libxml2" is following the CMake recommendation to match the official name of the library, however given the included target definitions "LibXml2::LibXml2" in recent CMake find scripts I would probably modify this now for backward compatibility.

The other patches follow a similar pattern, therefore libiconv is already included as a dependency in the libxml2 target for libxslt. For liblzma I still have to modify the patch to use the target name. Using targets for dependencies instead of traditional variables currently requires either a recent CMake version with a matching target-compatible find script or a dependency's CMake config file with a target definition. This currently works for my setup where I do the latter for all of my dependencies.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
I've now updated the patches above in order to match the capitalization used in CMake's find modules: LibLZMA::LibLZMA, ZLIB::ZLIB, Iconv::Iconv, LibXml2::LibXml2, LibXslt::LibXslt.

The find_package calls now first look for the config files and then fall back to using the find modules included in CMake for backwards compatibility while also defining any missing target definitions for older modules.

The traditional variables, e.g., LIBXML2_LIBRARIES, in the config files now avoid using a reference to the target definition and instead extract the library location from its target properties for users who still prefer this.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
I've added support for compiling the Python modules and fixed some minor issues after additional tests on various Ubuntu versions, MSVC 2017 and macOS 10.14.

Yes, the latest commit is the one at https://github.com/roboticslibrary/libxml2/tree/patch.

It would be great if you can also integrate the one for libxslt. The latest version is at https://github.com/roboticslibrary/libxslt/tree/patch.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
@traversaro Thanks for the suggestion, I'll add LIBXML2_ and LIBXSLT_ prefixes to the respective options/variables to support this use case.

@invy I'm sorry to hear you had problems when building libxslt with this. I've tested a lot of different configurations, but I may have missed one. Would you mind sharing some details on the specific issue you had, the platform/compiler/CMake version you're using, and ideally the error log?

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body: @traversaro I've just updated the patches for libiconv, liblzma, libxml2, and libxslt to use project-specific prefixes for the options.

events.target_title: Introduce CMake support

note.body:
@compnerd Thank you for testing. CMake 2.8.11 is the first version to support target_include_directories for a modern workflow. We still had to support a few older distributions with only that version when I created the patch and the there were no essential features missing so far.

CMAKE_VERSION is checked in some places to support PDB file installation (CMake 3.1) and newer find_package modules. I just noticed that INTERFACE and INTERFACE_LINK_LIBRARIES for targets require 3.0, but this could also be replaced with UNKNOWN and IMPORTED_LOCATION. Is there any specific feature that you're missing?

note.body:
> I don't think this whole commit is necessary for having a Flatpak of OCRFeeder since Flatpak can rename the files during the build.
> I don't mind having them changed though, so maybe we can keep it.

Although there are [some tricks](http://docs.flatpak.org/en/latest/flatpak-builder-command-reference.html#idm45850113011824) (`rename-desktop-file`, `rename-appdata-file`, `rename-icon`, `copy-icon`) that allow to change the Application ID during flatpak building, Flathub maintainers treat them as "_dirty hacks_", so they insist on changing the ID directly in the application.

https://github.com/flathub/flathub/pull/865#discussion_r257132623

> These renames should also happen in upstream repository.

note.body:
> So for this case I'd like to understand what was broken about the image preview, i.e. why is this patch needed.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run **OCRFeeder** _0.8.1_ e.g. on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
2. Add a image (`File` → `Add Image`)
3. Select a word.
4. Unpaper page (`Tools` → `Unpaper` → `OK`)

Image preview in the right pane (_Clip_) will not match the selected box.

https://i.paste.pics/c956a07720e9d5f14dd9d877acb78d6e.png

https://i.paste.pics/124fdee039f41dd1f9886f22438c0cfe.png

That's what I'm trying to fix here - force update of the box image preview (in fact there are two pixbufs in the right pane, plus one image in the main area).

events.target_title: Add various fixes

note.body:
> Why should we select the last one in the list?

Mainly to make **Tesseract** the default engine.

But it's not just that. Let's assume that you are trying to manage your OCR engines: add a new one (it could be the same engine you already have, but with different options), remove another, etc. Let's suppose that you added a new version of Tesseract and made it the default one. Unfortunately, you are not happy with the results (or you don't see any difference) and you want to remove it. When you do this, the favorite engine variable (`self.configuration_manager.favorite_engine` if I good remember) will match a value that not longer exist. This may even lead to inconsistencies between current configuration and UI. We need to make sure the new default engine will be selected in a predictable way.

The default list in my fork looks like this (sorted alphabetically by default):
1. Cuneiform
2. GOCR
3. Ocrad
4. Tesseract

We already know, that Tesseract is the best option, and Cuneiform is probably the worst. GOCR is somewhere in the middle. That's why I always want to select the last one.

Perhaps a link could be added from the former page to the latter.

events.target_title: Color management slowing performance

note.body:
I have looked into how x-rite and datacolor makers of colormunky display and spider5 they recommend for displays and scanners you use matrix profiles as this is what there proprietary software does by default and LUT's are for devices like printers.  So since the industry leaders in color management create matrix profiles by default that is what I'm going to do going forward by just telling displaycal to create curves+matrix and using over 700 patches to get good accuracy because matrix profiles are faster and LUT's slow down even the likes of Photoshop.  Here are two links from X-rite 

[](https://www.xrite.com/service-support/matrix_or_lut_based_profiles)

[](https://www.xrite.com/service-support/advanced_profile_settings)

events.target_title: password is stored (even if selected not to be remembered)

note.body:
Well, if you open your mail, get new messages, and never type your password, then it must be storing it somewhere.

However, we need to be sure that is the case and not just an issue of people being able to read mail that is already cached/downloaded without a password.  I think people are making a case that if you choose not to store the password, then the user should not be able to access ANY mail at all until the password is verified with the server.  And I agree that this would be the desired behavior.

events.target_title: Build from git source
Build from git source

note.body:
So far, I could manage (most probably) to _build_ it using the following commands: ```bash git clone git@gitlab.gnome.org:GNOME/ghex.git cd ghex meson build cd build ninja ninja test ``` `ninja-build test` however fails: ```bash $ ninja-build test [0/1] Running all tests. 1/2 Validate desktop file OK 0.02 s 2/2 Validate appstream file FAIL 0.31 s (exit status 1) OK: 1 FAIL: 1 SKIP: 0 TIMEOUT: 0 The output from the failed tests: 2/2 Validate appstream file FAIL 0.31 s (exit status 1) --- command --- /usr/bin/appstream-util validate --nonet data/org.gnome.GHex.appdata.xml --- stdout --- data/org.gnome.GHex.appdata.xml: FAILED: • style-invalid :

is too short [GHex can load raw data from binary files and display them for editing in the traditional hex editor view. The display is split in two columns, with hexadecimal values in one column and the ASCII representation in the other. A useful tool for working with raw data.] --- stderr --- Validation of files failed ------- Full log written to /home/ts/git/ghex/build/meson-logs/testlog.txt FAILED: meson-test /usr/bin/python3.6 -u /usr/bin/meson test --no-rebuild --print-errorlogs ninja: build stopped: subcommand failed. ``` And running `ghex/build/src/ghex` also fails: ```bash $ src/ghex (ghex:2401): GLib-GIO-ERROR **: 21:07:32.997: Settings schema 'org.gnome.GHex' is not installed Trace/breakpoint trap (core dumped) ``` There’s a note on the `gsettings` schema dir in `HACKING` file, particularly `GSETTINGS_SCHEMA_DIR=~/ghex/share/glib-2.0/schemas src/ghex`, but there is no `share` folder in this repo (nor it was created during the build process). I tried to modify this to `GSETTINGS_SCHEMA_DIR=data build/src/ghex`, but it also failed. Anyhow I tried to run `src/ghex`, it failed with the very same error above. ------- Anyway, I use CentOS 7 AMD64.

GIMP crash while trying to use Unsharp Mask
Request or bugfix - Gimp v2.10 please use lensfun packages already available rather than gimp-lensfun
Request or bugfix - Gimp v2.10 please use lensfun packages already available rather than gimp-lensfun

note.body:
Hi Elle Stone (Developer?), lillolollo, & Jehan (Developer?),

Thank you all for replying so quickly.

I know that I should post 2 comments rather than one, my bad.

As for asking the Gimp-LensFun plugin maintainer/developer, there does not seem to be any activity for over 2 years now, but I will make an issue post there as well.

What I was wondering before and I still am, is why the need for "gimp-lensfun" plugin when it appears to me that the "lensfun" packages are already installed or available to install and or can be easily compiled and installed which other image applications already use (Darktable, Rawtherapee, hugin, etc...)? Why can't Gimp 2.10.x use those instead of requiring the gimp-lensfun plugin?

I also agree that the developers of the various plug-ins should maintain and provide the appropriate updated versions for the newer Gimp versions rather than the Gimp developers although there is nothing wrong with Gimp developers and the various plugin developers collaborating together. Unless I am mistaken, it looks like "lensfun" is being maintained and updated only Gimp v2.10.x does not have a setting or an option to use them instead of the gimp-lensfun plugin? If there is a Gimp v2.10.x setting or some option or method to enable using the installed lensfun packages, please explain to me how to set that up?

Thank you again for any assistance with this. 

Best regards to all of you and yours,
Phil (phd21)

key events are not reported to accessibility layer any more in gtk4

note.body:
This is very bad news for people who rely on assistive technologies to use Linux or agencies required by law to have this support in their software. I understand that the existing solution isn't satisfactory, but could  lack of accessibility be marked as a blocker for whatever release is marked as stable and for use by applications?

As for what happens next, is there a roadmap on how to solve this? If it's a matter of labor, are there developers that could be sponsored to do this work?
